A very worthy sequel to the first game; this has some familiar mechanics taken from the first, but gameplay-wise, you can tell Supergiant has done their homework on what they can improve from an already excellent formula. Many new combat mechanics, different resources, and plenty more to discover breaking into Tartarus, and that's just scraping the surface.

Death to Chronos.

The video game is good. That's all for that.

Is It Better Than Hades 1. 

Okay, that's a great question, that's the real question. 

So, Hades 2 is a bigger, wider, harder game with a lot more to do do and discover. Truthfully it is Hades 2 & 3 stuck together. But-- if I'm gonna be so real, I think that Hades 1 is just... better? 

Okay, so this is gonna have big spoilers. For everything I guess.

[h1] **SPOILERS** [/h1]

So Hades 1 is this tight really well composed story about a boy and his dad and family and secrets. It's not heady, it's not esoteric, it's classic stuff. The gameplay is quick and snappy. The builds are fun. The zones can be kind of a drag. Elysium is a pain in the ass. 

Then Hades 2-- big epic story about you versus Time. CAN TIME NOT BE STOPPED? Then you gotta go to Olympus and FIGHT THE FATHER OF ALL MONSTERS. And it's all this stuff and all these things and its DIRE and SCARY and the tone is VERY dark and Chronos is extremely difficult and-- and then... 

And then it just stops? 

Then it just... stops. 

It just ends. And everyone lives happily every after?

So-- like... yeah, it just.. 

When you get to the point of Hades 1 where you're hearing "In The Blood" it feels like you've triumphed in so many ways. Your relationship with your family, your dad, you got your mom, your dog... it's so powerful. 

And in this one you just.. Well, someone ELSE does stuff and then...?

So, I'll be real, the gameplay is massively improved. The maps are fun. The weapons are different, largely fun. The combat is a bit slower but it feels better. I just don't feel like the story lived up to what I know Supergiant is capable of. This still feels like it's half finished. I don't know. It's worth your time. It's still amazing. It's just... not what it could have been.

[h2]Hades II [/h2]

After the announcement of the second part, I was skeptical. The studio had never made sequels before, and when something is created as a follow up because of financial success, it usually ends up being an average idea with lots of fan service.

I was glad to be wrong, and now I believe that the second part is not only no worse than the first, but it is hard for me to even say what exactly I missed or what could have been improved. Maybe a bit more drama in the ending could have been interesting, but that is a matter of personal taste.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3579464049
The mechanics became deeper, there are more of them now, including a greater variety of locations, bosses, enemies, trials, and companions. The game became bigger and higher quality, which is what you expect from a sequel, and at the same time it has its own style and vibe. Personally, I have nothing to criticize the game for.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3605563038
Some people might be put off by the fact that completing the main story requires more than fifty hours, and finishing all side quests and trials takes over one hundred. But in this sense it is only slightly larger than the first part, and this feels more like its specific feature than a drawback, especially because the gameplay is very addictive. When you get into it, you want to do one more run, and then another, and another, just like in the first game.

The story structure remains similar to the first part. The plot is built around the family of the main heroine and the special nature of relationships between gods and other beings of the underworld.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3580144772
You can say that the game became a bit harder than the first part and at the same time a bit easier. The meta progression offers more build options, and I would especially like to mention potion brewing, which feels very enjoyable.

It is a pity that this year Hades Two is unlikely to win the Best Indie Game award, although in my opinion it definitely deserves it and is absolutely a strong contender for the title.

The combination of stunning artwork, banger music, and addictive gameplay absolutely hits the mark. It's the perfect formula for a seriously good time.

Masssive kudos to Supergiant for delivering another brilliant entry into their line of incredible games. I really wasn't expecting all that much from a sequel to a [b]roguelike[/b] of all genres, and I especially wasn't expecting Hades 2 to top the masterpiece that was its predecessor.

Somehow, Supergiant has managed to deliver the same visually stylish, slick, and punchy combat from the first game, but elevated it to levels I didn't think possible. 
The wider variety of weapons, aspects, and boons on top of different zones made this a really fun experience. Progression also feels faster, which can take away some of that typical roguelike fatigue. 
The only downsides are IMO, a weaker story and more of a grind to get the epilogue, but the rest of the game is so good that none of that really detracts from the overall game.

Hades 2 is an action roguelike with a heavy focus on story and characters. As anyone can tell you, it’s good.

It’s quite similar to the first game. You go on dungeon runs, meet various characters during and between them, and there’s a lot of talking - with great voice acting and solid writing. Gameplay-wise, it’s probably better than its predecessor. Builds, combinations, variety of paths and enemies, optional challenges - it’s all there. Unlike the previous game, the character progression system isn’t just a series of straightforward upgrades for everything, but an interesting set of choices in itself. It also looks solid and sounds incredible. The character design is a little overwhelming, I feel (I’ll die on the hill that they should’ve kept Narcissus’ beta art), but it’s not off-putting. It’s good.

I’m less impressed with the story, and that’s an important part of the experience. Supergiant games are usually about subversion and this being a sequel to their previous game makes it a subversion of a subversion. So it ends up feeling rather straightforward and dull compared to the original. It’s mostly a revenge story with clear villains, and many of the storylines don’t fit this tone as well as the first game’s low-stakes, chill premise. Much of it feels forced, as if the developers felt obliged to include characters filling the same roles as Hades 1’s cast but couldn't find a good reason for them to be there. It’s still well written, mind you, but it feels repetitive, and most conversations seem to revolve around mutual respect and sympathy. Too saccharine, you know?

Still, I don’t regret the time spent with this game. Neither will you.

Finally some Hades again! I was almost addicted to the first game and couldnt wait for another serving, once i heard about it. And Hades 2 doesnt really disappoint. Hades 2 is in its world, characters and gameplay features almost twice as big as Hades 1. The new weapons, the inclusion of Magick, new bosses and the new Arcana cards are an interesting and innovative try to keep the gameplay loop fresh and to not copy the first game step-by-step. So that is a great plus. And they achieved just that. Combat also feels great and just as snappy as the first game. 

I do have some caveats though.
First, they didnt want to copy the mechanics of certain Olympian gods from the first game. I get that. But some gods' boons just feel so..... characterless. In the first game, i knew exactly in what direction certain Olympian boons would take me. In Hades 2 many of them just feel so mushy. It is hard to explain...
Second, not only have the world and the features doubled in quantity, but also the amount of collectable resources, upgradeable items and their requirement to unlock stuff. The grind is far worse than in Hades 1.
Three, i finished the story in 1.0 and it felt rushed, incomplete and weird. There were quite a few narrative holes. They tried to fix that and did fix it to a good degree in the most recent patch as of writing this review, but to me that was a big no-no. Dont release your game as finished when you have such a directionless story. That was very uncharacteristic of Supergiant. And i am not the only one. I scoured many forums like Steam and Reddit, where also a decent number of people expressed their consternation about that original ending.
Four, the relationships between the characters sometimes feel either forced or shallow or both. Especially the romantic ones. Exceptions apply, of course. But overall they felt a bit more authentic and natural in the first game.

However, despite my negative points of criticism, i am very happy with Hades 2. The game is a ton of fun and i will definitely keep playing the Tartarus out of it, easily reaching the 200 hour mark. If you liked the first game, then Hades 2 will leave you capitivated and satisfied, guaranteed. Even though i would consider the first game to be an all-in-all better experience. But trying to topple the masterpiece that is Hades 1 is an almost impossible feat anyway.

I loved the first Hades - it was an incredibly personal story with great replayability and really enjoyable rogue-lite design. The tight gameplay loop, unforgettable characters and Darren Korb's soundtrack made every run feel meaningful and pushing the story further

Here's how I felt about the sequel:
 - gameplay - it's an upgraded version of OG Hades, refining what already worked and adding meaningful depth - I really enjoyed it and actually prefer more than OG Hades now. Selene's mechanics, the emphasis on spells weapons (a dream for mage fans like myself), new companions and expanded boon variety create incredible synergy possibilities. With so many options, the base game feels easier, but that can be adjusted later for more challenge
- music and sounds - Darren Korb has done it again. The soundtrack is phenomenal, don't have anything to say, 11/10
- visuals - it's Hades, but polished. The attention to detail in animations and art direction is impressive without overshadowing the foundation that made the original beautiful. Witch theme is also nuts
- dialogues - well-written, you don't get tired over campaign + the voiceover also amazing

Not pros, but not cons either:
- plot - This is where Hades 2 stumbles compared to the original. The story feels less personal, less intimate. OG Hades wrapped you in a tightly, human-scale narrative where Zagreus's desire for truth and connection drove everything forward. Hades 2 swaps that for grand, fate-deciding stakes and paradoxically, it makes the story feel smaller and more generic. The plot beats are predictable, mysteries are non-existent and you end up trudging through a predetermined sequence of events rather than uncovering something. It's serviceable, but it lacks the dramatic punch of what came before

- characters - Melinoe is well-developed with genuine depth and certain characters like Selene, Captain Schmemelus, Arachne and, ofc, Cerberus with Bouldy, are quite interesting. But honestly? Most of the cast feels like they're just... there. They hit familiar archetypes and typical story beats you'd find in every other game. There's little that makes them memorable or unique. Some character arcs even seem to just end right after the quest, without any epilogue for their story line. Compared to OG Hades' roster - where almost every character felt like someone you genuinely connected with - this cast feels generic by comparison. They're not bad, but I won't be thinking about them months from now

///
Despite the narrative weaknesses, I still love Hades 2 for what it gets right - I even completed 100% of achievements and had fun doing that. The enhanced gameplay, the mechanical depth and the quality of combat make it an exceptional rogue-lite experience. I'll absolutely replay it in future. Supergiant made a sequel that's more fun to play than the original, even if it's less compelling to experience

[b]Somehow, "Hades 2" manages to grow, evolve and surpass the original masterpiece. It doubles the number of regions you can explore and introduces fresh ideas, characters, and design elements. Once again, it shines with its stunning art style, brilliant level design, state-of-the-art gameplay, fast-paced combat, smooth animations, outstanding voice performances, and phenomenal music.
But the developers didn’t stop there. Their deep knowledge of Greek mythology, immersive storytelling, unique NPCs, and beautifully written dialogue elevate the game into something truly special. It’s not just about slaying foes—it’s about building relationships, uncovering lore, and experiencing a world that feels alive. "Hades 2" is another landmark achievement in the roguelike genre.


Manometer: 9/10[/b]


The good
- Artistic brilliance. Gorgeous toon-style 3D graphics packed with intricate details. Conversations feature stylish sketch-like character portraits. The color palette is rich, and the world design is atmospheric, spanning eight distinct locations—from the depths of the underworld to the peak of Mount Olympus, literally twice the size of the original game.
- Great concept. The infinite loop serves both symbolic and gameplay purposes. Each death isn’t just a setback—it’s a narrative evolution. New events and dialogues emerge, making every run feel meaningful.
- One of the most immersive and deep gameplays out there. It combines close-quarters and ranged tactics with a variety of weapons and upgrades. Casting is not just a complementary mechanic, but opens up diverse strategic approaches. Combat is rhythmic, fast, and satisfying—an upgrade over, the already great, original.
- Immersive, responsive controls. Every button press feels intuitive and precise. You feel fully in control of Melinoe’s movements.
- Smooth animations. Visually pleasing and gameplay-enhancing, the animations are fluid and impactful
- Perfect balance between randomness and linearity. You don't feel lost or bored inside a random generated world because the story follows your actions. Also during each run characters you meet follow the story, remember your actions, can see your weapon, keepsake or boon and comment accordingly. Everything evolves organically with both randomness and logic. 
- High replay value. Each run feels fresh thanks to weapon and boon combinations. Discovering powerful builds—sometimes by sheer luck—is thrilling. Also you can always add some fear in order to make it even more challenging and different. 
- Rich mythology. The developers clearly did their homework. Every character and event is steeped in accurate mythological detail, from gods’ personalities and relationships to obscure NPC backstories
- Remarkably well written dialogues. Surprisingly emotional and profound for a combat-focused game. Each character has a distinct voice and personality. Conversations remain engaging even dozens of hours in. The amount of dialogues is endless and you keep taking new ones even a lot of hours after finishing the game. 
- Diverse enemies and NPCs. Enemies have varied attack patterns, and NPCs, like ancient Gods, heroes and mythological creatures are creatively reimagined in a vibrant anime-inspired style. Melinoe is a standout protagonist—dark yet kind-hearted. Dora is a charming and fitting successor to Dusa.
- Animal companions. A delightful addition that also adds gameplay depth.
- It is well balanced and very rewarding. Early defeats teach you the mechanics. As you grow stronger, the challenge remains, but victories feel earned and satisfying.
- Fantastic voice acting performances. Some of the voices are really unique and unforgettable.
- Great music. From tranquil tunes at the Crossroads to intense rock and metal tracks during battles, the soundtrack enhances every moment. Skyla’s story and songs add emotional weight to the musical experience.
- Awesome, balanced sense of humor. The game never takes itself too seriously, but it also respects its darker themes.
- Sandbox elements. Decorating and upgrading the Crossroads isn’t essential, but it’s oddly satisfying to create a cozy home for yourself and your companions.
- Advanced crafting. More complex than the original, with many diofferent resources to gather, incarnations to forge, and even a small farm to cultivate.
- Immersive design choices. The Arcana Cards system is visually and thematically richer than the original game’s mirror interface.

The bad
- Both Hades games have remarkable level design, I cannot stop praising it. Yet, "Fields of Mourning" region in Hades 2 is problematic and disrupts the game’s rhythm. Wandering in circles to find boons kills the momentum. I was bored of playing the underworld because of this region. Especially with time control. it becomes so annoying when you cannot find the boons. Exploration doesn't fit this game.
- Main story events require a fair number of runs, which is fine. But after a point, side stories and dialogue start to feel stagnant. Post-game progression lacks organic evolution—you’re stuck in 20-minute loops chasing minor changes. Roguelikes thrive on repetition, but it needs to be paired with meaningful growth. I 100% completed the game to see everything, but the final stretch felt a bit exhausting. 
- Some frustrating achievements. Some are needlessly convoluted—not due to difficulty, but randomness. The epilogue (finding the Fates) is especially annoying, requiring intentional deaths that random events can sabotage. Other achievements depend on rare spawns with no reliable strategy to increase your chances.

Yes, there are a lot more resources to gather and keep track of, nut resources come in more often and faster than in the first game. 

Secondly, the characters are more memorable and better written. It's not necessarily a big upgrade from the first game, but the best way I can put it is that their implementation and interactions are a bit more diverse. Despite having about double the cast of characters, it doesn't feel like it's too much.

Another huge upgrade from the first game is combat. Being able to sprint makes combat a lot more fluid, and it really does feel better with a controller. The weapons are much more engaging. In the first game the primary and special attacks for each weapon felt like "I hit this way" and "I hit this way but harder", respectively. In this game they are very different. In addition, both the primary and special have a charge attack, giving much more potential variety in combat. And to top combat off there is a greater variety of enemies.

I want to start by saying that despite everything I wrote in this review, I really liked this game (obvious considering I put almost 40 hours into it in less than 2 weeks). It took a lot of the story and mechanics from Hades and made them bigger and better, was visually stunning, and I enjoyed the character designs and soundtrack even more than the first game. Melinoë is a well-written character and definitely in my list of favorite game protagonists. While I truly did enjoy experiencing the first parts of Hades II, and I fully intend to keep playing it, there were a few things that dragged it down enough that I had to pick not recommended (mostly because there isn't a "maybe" or "kind of" option). I still recommend playing it and forming your own opinion because some of these things might have just been me.

Number one, the ending. I've been made aware that the ending I played was the updated "fixed" one, and I still think that it seriously does not do this story or its characters justice. I won't go into detail to avoid too many spoilers but it felt incredibly rushed and like it took a lot of agency away from Melinoë, ignoring a lot of the motivations at the core of her character. Your mantra for this entire game is "Death to Chronos", and the player is made to feel this through hours of getting taunted and defeated by him, but after one 2-minute cutscene they decide he can be redeemed and he quickly goes from a great villain to a mediocre NPC. I think an ending like that could work and be interesting narratively, but there needs to be more of a setup + follow through instead of a short cutscene straight into credits. It also makes post-game runs less enjoyable because the reasons for Melinoë to be doing them don't make a lot of sense.

Number two, the progression. At first I really enjoyed the introduction of two paths to take (Underworld/Olympus) as it adds a lot of content and opens up the world more, but the difference in difficulty between the two areas combined with the non-linear progression through them made the experience less appealing. Having to ping-pong back and forth between the two areas to complete the story was frustrating considering how different the scaling was, and with the addition of even more mechanics and materials in this game it was hard to have a consistent build for getting to the final bosses. A lot of it felt like pure luck when in the first game you could reliably get a solid build going most of the time.

The final issue I had which is incredibly nitpicky and probably just a me thing was the sheer amount of materials in the game. I'm obviously not unfamiliar with grinding to get certain materials since that was a major mechanic in the first game, but the amount of them combined with my previous points on the progression made it frustrating to complete upgrades or even just minor QOL changes from the incantations.

While I intend to keep playing this game, I can see the gameplay loop after the story starting to feel like a chore and I'm not sure how many more hours I'll get out of it before I just go replay the first game again lol.

I hate to give this game a bad review but the ending squashed all positive feelings I had for it. The ending was cut short and left me feeling like the entire game was for nothing. Nemesis is so cool that sometimes I wonder if she would have been a better protagonist. Medea is another really cool character with a distinctive somber persona. Scylla and the sirens, what a remarkable boss. She is as memorable as Thesius. A charismatic foe that you love to hate. The best songs of the game come from her confrontation.

Some minor complaints and suggestions before the big one. The reagents and greeneries should be used for more enchantments and relationship progression. In the current state of the game, the majority of them are barely used, just keep filling up space, and are just a waste of time to collect once used. Supergiant could add incantations to the relationship system of the game instead of heavily relying on nectar and ambrosia. Melinoe could do strange and funny incantations she thinks might help her acquaintances, but which could backfire. She isn't as cheeky as Zagreus, but her naivete could be used to add some funny moments to the game. She could give some rare reagents and greeneries to Hecate, Circe, Medea, and maybe Arachne. She could give rare reagents to Icarus and Hephaestus. Give Persephone some greeneries. Her mother would love to receive flowers from her daughter. Mix things up. Not just give the same thing to everybody.

Most relationships in Hades 2 have a dissatisfying development and conclusion. The alliance with the Olympian gods plays exactly like the first game so they didn't feel anything special. A suggestion here would be Melinoe learn how to infuse nectars and ambrosias through incantations to please the gods. Sort of like the ectoplasmic draught she makes for Icarus. Different gods requiring different incantations. Regarding the relations with the other NPCs, there is a clear difference between Hades and Hades 2. Zagreus helps all those who help him throughout the game. It is extremely gratifying to interact with them. Melinoe in contrast just seems to meet them and become an acquaintance to most of them. Even if you advance all relationships in the game, she is just someone these people know and have to interact occasionally. There is no emotional benefit to befriending most characters. It is just something to unlock more dialogue. It is purely transactional. In the first Hades, it is so rewarding to help Achilles, your mentor and guy who has been encouraging you and being positive throughout the whole game. Dusa, Nyx, Sysiphus, Patroclus, Eurydice, Orpheus, Megaera, etc. It feels great meeting, talking, befriending, and helping them. There is nothing like that in Hades 2. I did not like to face Cerberus as a boss. I love him in the first game. He is a source of comfort. You only see him in combat for a brief moment in the advanced final boss fight, which is hilarious (bad boy, bad boy!). You turned a character that I loved in the first game into a character that I loathe having to face every single time I go to the Underworld. It makes no sense that he keeps getting corrupted even after you have freed Hades and Persephone.

If Chronos can imprison powerful characters like Zagreus, Persephone, and Hecate in those time bubbles; why doesn't he do that to Milenoe? This is a plot hole to me. In my head, I kept thinking how cool it would have been if Hecate had planned to make Milenoe's true identity to Chronos a secret because her main advantage would be that since she is directly related to him, his powers of time would not be reliable against her. Everyone who is directly related to Chronos would have this advantage. Only in later encounters he would deduce who she really is. I imagined him freezing her. After one or two seconds she frees herself, he shouts "impossible!", and the song "In the Blood" starts to play as the final fight progresses. But if I need to make mental gymnastics to justify your story, then there is definitely something wrong.

Now the big complaint. The first time I reached each of the endings of the first Hades it felt like bliss. When I reached the first ending of Hades 2, it just made the game worse and worse. It felt like some Kung Pow Enter the Fist type of joke, but done seriously.

Milenoe: I have diligently trained my entire life to kill the man who took my family away from me. I will never forgive him. Not in a million years. Never.
Zagreus: I implore you to reconsider.
Milenoe: Hmm... (in a high pitched voice) Okay. Hey grandpa, you are forgiven.

Chronos: For millennia, I painfully reconstituted myself after having been slain by my own children. Now it is my children's turn to suffer through my rightful revenge!
Zagreus: I implore you to reconsider.
Chronos: Hmm... (in a high pitched voice) Okay. Hey family, sorry.

Two tales of revenge. One from the protagonist and one from the antagonist. They both end in an awkward family reunion. That is bullshit. Shoving a happy ending when it isn't earned just left me with a huge feeling of disappointment. Every time I met with the reformed Chronos, I rolled my eyes. The post ending justification of having to battle other timelines is such a lazy excuse. The writer wrote himself into a corner and came up with this lousy trick. Suddenly we have a multiverse to fight for eternity. Give me a break.

If I had to describe this game in one word, it would be unsatisfying. After all those hours invested in this story, you are left with a pitifully weak ending. Then play more to reach the true ending, and it is another huge let down. The meeting with the Fates is extremely underwhelming. Just like waking up Hypnos. Then you get Hecate's reveal which is a convoluted time travel mess. It made me think what was the point of it all. What a waste of my time. I have occasionally reinstalled the first Hades a couple of times to beat it once again since it is so much fun. If I had to describe the first game in one word, it would be rewarding. After uninstalling Hades 2, I will probably never play it again. I paid full price in early access only because I bought the first game in a discount and loved it so much I promised I would pay full price for the next game.

If you are planning to buy this game, most likely you have played the first Hades. If you don't care much about the story and are only interested in the game mechanics or the speed running aspect, go for it. It is as good as the predecessor. If you care about the story, I would advise to only buy this game on a very big discount. While the game is fun, the story is extremely unsatisfying.

The short review is: play the first game, it's awesome. This one's a lame copy. 

The long one is: I really wanted to love this game. The first one was one of the best games I've ever played and I've played a lot. However, I simply can't. And for many reasons: 

1. One of the finest characteristics of the first game was how balanced it was. Each weapon had some advantages, same for the gods. And none was truly broken. You had to do your best. Now... Well, now there are many broken combos. And you don't even need them. Just get a Selene damaging boon, improve it, get loads of life and nothing else matters. You can one-shot each phase of the final boss with it. And with enough life you don't really need to bother too much with his attacks. No strategy or ability required. This game is way easier than the first without being more interesting.
2. This game pretends to have more options, but they are not really options. For instance, would you rather have three extra lives or deal more damage to enemies with two curses? Most of the options you have are either super powerful or mostly useless. For instance, one of the challenges of the game is to manage you mana consumption. However you can choose to start with a powerful mana regen, which makes mana management moot.
3. Far too many resources, most of which are used once or twice, then become irrelevant. The game itself knows it and at some point gives you a magic that makes you not even have to gather them. 
4. The conversations are boring. There are far too many characters and you have to give far too many gifts to each of them, and your reward is too listen to same sentence with different words. Besides, almost everyone is super nice ever since the beginning. There's no drama and no evolution to the characters. The gods even apologize when you spurn them.
5. Most of the characters are very tedious. The headmistress is a fortune cookie sentence generator. Odysseus only alerts you to things that you already know. (By the gods! The skeleton has better advice.) Very few characters have something interesting to say.
6. The love interests are lame. Two weak, apologetic men. (One of them actually apologizes to you for having only you as a lover while you have a lot of people.) One woman hates you and does everything she can to make your life worse. (Really? That's the one the main character is going after!?) Only the other woman has a nice story and doesn't seem a lame lover.
7. The antagonist could be easily swapped by Doc. Evil, given how cliche he is. And the ending (both of the main story and the epilogue) are super boring. 

The only saving grace was Scylla. The idea of a boss that sings different songs throughout her level is awesome. And her songs are much more interesting than the bgm of the rest of the game.

All in all, this was not a good sequence to the first. Having played Silksong recently, the difference in quality is glaring. Whereas in Silksong the creators clearly learned from the first game and made an even better one, in this game no lessons were learned. In fact, there were many downgrades that I simply cannot understand. 

For instance, when checking a god's boon list, in the first game you could see simultaneously both the requirements and the details of the boon. Now you can see only one or the other. Who thought this would be better? On the first, after you finished the main quest, the ending of a run was a lighthearted joke on the protagonist. Now we have only a boring generic ending. Is the protagonist so soft skinned that she can't take a joke?

My take on this game is that this game was not thoroughly thought before its implementation and that early access made it worse instead of better. The loudest people usually ask for a less challenging game and for more OP characters, which can be fun for a little while but make for a much less enjoyable game.

For instance, the last weapon to be created requires no brain to play. Just spam super specials and that's it. Super boring. I did the 32 darkness challenge with it at the beginning of the game without breaking a sweat. This should not happen. In the end, the hardest challenge is to play the super random challenge, where you may end with the lamest weapon and worse enemy boosts. Not fun at all.

The rogue-like cancer that's affected game design has only grown bigger and it seems Hades 2 doubled down on it instead of decently controlled difficulty (which it had the room to do) it copped out for the rogue-like elements that make a game "hard" instead. So here is a break down of all the flaws a rogue-like has that this game didn't (refused to) fix:

1) Weapon Imbalance - the playstyles in the weapons can feel a little different at first which is pleasant but to say they are equally balanced is saying snow is brown. It is bizarre, how drastically pointless the majority of the weapons actually are and the Boons offered, although with a greater variety, I'm afraid do not equally lean toward them either. The degree to which the staff needs to be molded, catered, babied, insert-appropriate-word-for-a-shit-ton-of-effort-here, in order to be as effective as hitting someone with a big axe, is so absurd you need a degree from a lovecraftian university to comprehend it. It's a rogue-like level-based beat em up. The fun comes from the leveling up and building being effective tools to play with and for some of the weapons it literally is never worth the effort.

2) "What the fuck is going on?" - You've said this phrase playing any bullet-hell rogue-like. You have. I have. The devs did when testing but kept it because it makes things "difficult". To put this into perspective, once you have reached the higher difficulties of this game, there is a point where every creature can have:
1) an aura of a certain color that does something you hope you learned about 
2) they either shoot little projectiles of a certain color all over the screen for you to dodge
3) they have a horribly animated melee attack (which is just basically a teleport where you have no i-frames dodging through) but don't worry they glow a certain color right before they do that
4) they channel a nasty half-the-map-sized spell that deals fuck tons of damage but don't worry they have a big circle on the ground in 1 of 3 colors 
and/or 
5) they have 2 different kinds of armor but don't worry they glow colors to show you how many and which ones they.
Now gee wiz that sounds at least telegraphed right? I mean it's overwhelming sure but at least you know what's happening to some degree right? Nope. You sounded stupid reading that, I sure hope it wasn't out loud. Because all of these are the same 3 colors which, coincidentally, happen to be the same colors you produce by:
1) Attacking animation colors of certain weapons of yours
2) Colorful circles on the ground you cast
3) Enhancements to your weapons by gods that are 1 of 3 colors
4) Your dash effects giving by gods of 1 of 3 colors
5) The conditions you place on top of the already colored enemies given by the gods of 1 of 3 colors
6) Your projectiles that are 1 of 3 colors
7) Your animal companion dashing around doing attacks in 1 of 3 colors
8) the dangers and explosions of the maps in 1 of 3 colors
9) don't worry, I'll use my new cool moon power that acts like a big charge up weapon/spell. What does this one do? Oh it charges a big beam that's 1 of 3 colors? The other one? Oh shoots a big ball of 1 of 3 colors. The other one? Summons an enemy you killed who LOOKS LIKE THE ENEMIES SHOOTING YOU WHILST SHOOTING THEM WITH THE SAME PROJECTILES AND NO INDICATION OF WHICH IS WHICH IS GIVEN AND EVEN IT WAS IT WOULDN'T HELP-WHY NOT-OH BECAUSE IT'D JUST BE 1 OF 3 COLORS! ARE YOU SEEING THE PATTERN YET!?
It becomes impossible to tell what the hell is going on because they flood you with an impossible bunch of colorful, fast-moving stimuli that unless you are a 10 year old with a ton of sugar in you you won't ever be able to logically ascertain what is happening let alone react to it.

You can see this for yourself by simply quitting and replaying it. Meaning the "difficulty" of the random boons is somewhat scripted and it feel cheap knowing that I might not get what I need not because of a random chance, but rather because the devs decided to be mean or simply not piece together that that build could exist. [h1]Overhyped Disappointment[/h1] 
The developers were once known for experimenting with different genres. It’s a shame those experiments seem to have ended, and instead we got a game that could have easily been just a DLC (and in that case, there would’ve been no complaints).

The first Hades was a breakthrough title that showed for the first time that roguelikes can have high-quality narrative and storytelling — all wrapped in Supergiant Games’ signature art direction. For many people, the original Hades became the showcase of the action-roguelike genre and the entry point into it (myself included). Despite its click-click-dash combat, the game delivered a fresh and exciting experience.
What experience does Hades II offer? With such tedious combat and build-crafting, it can easily push players away from the genre entirely: “If the overhyped Hades II is this boring, then other roguelikes must be even worse.”

At first, I wanted to describe all the issues, but once I started writing, I realized I’d spend an enormous amount of time. It’s not worth it. There are already many great negative reviews with detailed examples and explanations. So here’s a short summary of the game’s problems:
[list]
[*]The combat became broader, but not deeper. Just like before — it’s simply click-click-dash.
[*]Battle balance is broken. Normal difficulty is extremely easy, while higher difficulty is absurd and tedious.
[*]The balance of boons and build-crafting is questionable. The dominant strategy is to pick the highest damage percentages for your basic or special attack and spam it. There are far too many useless boons.
[*]The Arcana system is dark-meta that effectively gets removed at high difficulty.
[*]Resource grind and the grind animations show no respect for the player’s time.
[/list]
What I simply disliked:
[list]
[*]The visual style
[*]The story feels childish, the characters are weak, and the developer-intended ending doesn’t match the dark and brutal tone of Greek mythology
[/list]
If you haven’t played the first Hades, go play it. And if you have, you’re better off trying Curse of the Dead Gods instead.

I'm annoyed at this game.  I don't think it's even remotely on the level of Hades 1, and there is not one quality of life or any improvement I could name about the game that sets the bar higher than the previous title.

  I think Hades 2 punishes the player directly or indirectly for too many things, has too much bullet hell mechanics, too much indiscriminite crap happening on screen making it impossible to predict (especially when considering your own boon effects visually proc-ing), too many mediocre min-maxed boons, mediocre pets, mediocre weapons, mediocre story progression, mediocre music except for a couple of tunes that shine (Olympus Aflame, Siren battles etc).  The game feels to me as if the developers watched too many speed runs of their previous game, and forgot that the vanilla game doesn't need to be in an arms race with insane speed runners who have nothing else to do.

Why not let the player take more boons in the first area on the way to Olympus similar to the rat maze?  Then restrict the rooms later via heat level?  Why am I staring at 8 rooms and only able to choose 6?  I honestly want to install a mod manager for the game because getting the combination you want is less likely to happen across time than the heat death of the entire cosmos.  The game could probably be balanced IMO easily by simply adding like 2-3 chambers/encounters per region.

Why are the chaos trials so fun, yet the builds from those trials are utterly and completely unbuildable?  Yet another unintentional punishment to the player "here is something you can never do nor achieve! enjoy!"  If the odds of a deck of 52 cards being shuffled is basically guaranteed to be unique - then the odds of a single Hades 2 game is probably unique with more than twice or thrice as many combinations.  I challenge someone to figure out the math on it.  How the heck did they even playtest it then, is also my question.  Clearly they didn't in some cases (Hermes boon that affects percentages gets nerfed on Sea Star if you level up Sea Star later for example).

  I'm having a difficult time enjoying any of it, and just fizzling out on heat level 6 Olympus runs because the heat level bosses are just stupid.  I never felt this way about Hades 1 heat level bosses, it was always epic and exciting getting amped for the plus level boss fights.  Now it's like "what random 2-frame timing projectile bullshit are they going to throw at me now".  Too much projectile hell in a world where you basically never get Athena's dash.  It's nearly impossible to get a decent intentional build, and even when I do ( for example just did a run where I got a Zeus + Hera duo boon granting me +12 on all my zeus boons) but then of course I have like 1 death defiance left because the poison battle with Medea and Polyphemus is absolute and pure bullshit, and then the fight with whats-her-bucket after that will finish you off.

It feels like this game never left beta, and I'm just not excited to play it anymore, or even finish the story.  It's extremely frustrating.  Melinoe is possibly one of the most boring characters written in the history of games, she isn't exactly unpleasant at least.  She seems to be the kind of girl girls would aspire to see themselves as, fair enough.  But just bland as pouring baking flour in your oatmeal.  The only carrot is the story of Melinoe's family dragging me along, and it's so few and far between that this story develops, it makes Persephone's presence in the previous game seem like she practically lived in Tartarus.

I'm leaving a negative for a very specific, almost niche reason. If you own this game on two platforms (Switch 2 and PC in my case), be very careful on the cross-save mechanic. You can sync both platforms to use one save. If you quit out of the Switch 2 version by closing the game to the "desktop" of Switch, that save can absolutely be lost and the previous save on the Switch will overwrite progress made on Steam.

In my case, my 30 hours played on PC was lost and the 5 hours played on Switch overwrote the Steam save, reverting the progress much further back. Admittedly this is user error on my part for not quitting and saving in-game and doesn't reflect the quality of the game itself.

The only reason for the negative review is because of this instance and is a warning for others to be mindful of, if you choose to use cross-saves between different platforms.

Hades II is a difficult game to review. On the one hand, the gameplay is still excellent, better in some ways than the first. On the other hand, so many other aspects of the game are considerably worse.

By far the biggest problems are the story and the characters. Hades had a tight story about Zagreus, his family and their relationships. Every character you encountered had a part to play in the overall story and your relationship with them would evolve over the course of the story. Every conversation would reveal more of the backstories and relationships of the characters, which both advanced the main plot and fleshed out each character you talked to.

Hades II's story on the other hand is a basic, boring revenge story with a horrendous, abrupt ending. An ending so bad they immediately tried to fix it. Gone are almost all of the interesting conversations with other characters, almost every one boils down to "Wow, I had never heard of you before", "This is what is happening in the story", or "You're so awesome and you're the only one who can do anything".  Why would the gods take essentially no action other than giving boons when they should have both the desire and capability to do more?

Also, so many aspects of the game are "bigger" than the first, but are often to the detriment of the overall experience. Having to collect all the different resources needed to progress is a slog. The indicator of a good system is not to have the end goal be to finally get to ignore the system almost entirely. And far more character power is locked behind the several progression systems. You will lose runs, not from playing badly, but because farming the copious resources takes forever. Do you need one specific resource for a key upgrade? It could take double-digit runs before you get another chance at it. 

Instead of having well designed, interesting arenas, most of the maps are just a wide open space. Do you like needing map markers to find where things are on the map quickly? And oh, you need to both unlock the markers and activate them on each stage. How fun.

Lastly, the boons are far more powerful than in the original, but lack the ability to meaningfully change how you play. Each weapon plays essentially the same regardless of the boons you get. And some combinations of boons are so absurdly overpowered, it feels like a waste to pick anything else.

So I really like this game and enjoy playing it, just like I liked the first, but 2 in particular has a really glaring and obnoxious design flaw that is egregious enough to warrant a negative review. Straight up: there are WAY too many projectiles in the game, even in the base playthrough starting in the 4th zone, but it's really obnoxious when you start adding the night difficulties. It's not challenging, it's just annoying to continuously take chip damage from things you can't even see, while having to carefully kite and throw out one single ranged attack every few seconds to avoid being hit by the *literally* 20-30 projectiles shot at you or orbiting around the zone at once.

It's a game of limited health and health restore, yet there is constant chip damage from the dozens of tiny projectiles that get flung at you that you literally cannot see under the clutter of your own attack effects. I think that's objectively bad design. It's one thing in an ARPG like PoE where health regen is not a precious and limited resource, but it's strange that  Supergiant thought this way okay. It almost seems like it's there just to prevent/challenge the "no hit" speedrunner minority.
